awd_titl_txt: Temple University Graduate Student Conference in Algebra, Geometry, and Topology
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation award provides support for the next three events in a conference series at Temple University that brings together around one hundred graduate students at all levels from a variety of backgrounds and universities, along with four distinguished plenary speakers that work at the interface of algebra, geometry, and topology. The 2019 conference will occur on June 1-2. The next two will be held on similar dates in 2020 and 2021. The conference provides an opportunity for a large number of young mathematicians with similar research interests to come together and develop mathematical relationships. The conference strongly supports interactions between graduate students and plenary speakers in formal and informal settings. This gives graduate students the chance to make connections with mathematicians outside of their respective universities and fields of study. Both speakers and participants are selected with attention to recruitment from under-represented groups in the field.

These conferences include a wide range of topics coming from Geometric Topology, Geometric Group Theory, Representation Theory, Homotopy Theory and Noncommutative Algebra.  Talks given by distinguished plenary speakers provide insights into how different parts of algebra, geometry, and topology are connected, present open research questions of interest, and describe recent techniques used in groundbreaking work in these fields. Moreover, the organizing committee is driven by the participation of Temple graduate students with faculty support and guidance, providing the students with several professional development opportunities. The conference website is at https://math.temple.edu/events/conferences/gscagt/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided support for the annual Temple Graduate Student Conference in Algebra, Geometry, and Topology for the years 2019, 2021, 2022, and 2023. These were the fourth through eighth editions of the conference. The 2020 conference was canceled on account of the COVID-19 pandemic and the 2021 conference was held as an online event, while the 2019, 2022, and 2023 conferences were in-person events held at Temple University. The intellectual merit and broader impacts of the conference were centered around providing the opportunity for graduate students studying algebra, geometry, and topology - all broadly considered - to make professional connections, learn new mathematics, and obtain novel exposure to cutting-edge research in an environment tailored toward their success and development.

Each conference consisted of roughly 70 to 100 graduate student participants. The conference's location in Philadelphia allows for significant national impact: the conference is both easily accessible to students from throughout the Northeast corridor, and Philadelphia is a major airline hub, allowing students from more isolated locations (geographically and mathematically) a rare opportunity to interact with a large number of peers from in and around their area of specialization. Of the participants, roughly 33 gave 30 minute presentations, either on their research or an expository talk. Feedback forms collected after each talk allowed the speakers to obtain anonymous comments from their peers. This allowed presenters to practice the art of giving talks in a low-pressure, friendly environment, and allowed attendees to see new mathematical research being conducted by their peers. Student talks were selected to provide both a variety of topics and a diverse set of speakers. This environment also has proven results in developing new collaborative projects between young mathematicians. The majority of this award went funding participant travel and housing for the conference.

In addition, each conference featured four faculty plenary speakers that are renowned not only for their high-quality research, but also the quality of their mathematical exposition. The majority of the plenary speakers were from under-represented groups. These speakers not only provided talks that highlighted a variety of connections between algebra, geometry, and topology, but also spent a significant amount of time interacting with graduate students beyond their talks. This award also funded plenary speaker travel and accommodation.

To encourage social interaction, this award helped facilitate a number of social activities, including multiple coffee and tea breaks. This helped research discussions to continue beyond the brief question and answer sessions during talks, which was a major project goal. Starting in 2021, the conference included a moderated panel discussions on topics like professional development, diversity, equity, and inclusion in mathematics, grant-writing, and academic jobs. Participants also had the opportunity to interact with the panelists. For the in-person conferences, panelist travel and accommodation were supported by this award.

The conference also has professional impact on Temple PhD students that serve as student organizers under the mentorship of the faculty organizers (the PI and co-PI on this award), providing them with unique professional preparation. The graduate student organizers choose speakers, manage communication with participants, develop a presentation schedule, construct and maintain the website, organize social activities, promote the event, and facilitate events during the conference. A number of younger graduate students are included in organizing major components of this conference through subcommittees, and these students have always developed into passionate organizers of later editions of the conference that sustain its momentum.

Comments from post-conference feedback forms speak to the success the conference had in meeting its goals during the award period:

  • "This was the best conference of its kind I had attended. I thought the quality of graduate student talks was very high. The conference itself was organized very professionally."
  • "As a second-year student just starting research, it was really helpful for me to meet other people in the field for the first time and hear about what they are doing."
  • "I had been looking forward to meeting a certain professor for several months, and ended up hanging out with him a lot at the conference! It was a very fruitful conversation about my professional future."
  • "I was amazed by how many people I was able to connect with regarding our mutual research interests."
